channel.title: Some Guidance
channel.description:
Hello everyone!
I'm in need of some help with the following: -Simulating clicks to an applet -Locating a findcolor function specifically to a loaded applet and with the ability of minimization
If anybody could provide some advice or even source code to lead me in the right direction I'd be more than grateful.
Speedster239...

item.title: Some Guidance
item.dc:creator: @r0lor r0lor
item.description:
@r0lor wrote:

java.awt.Canvas.dispatchEvent(Event) in you’re case, I see you’re working on a bot?
Also, Rictoo, NullPointerExceptions at line 6 and line 7. Don’t start thinking it’s auto-initialized like it is in C(++)

Read full topic

item.title: Some Guidance
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

hence is the miracle of pointers

this takes me back to when i was learning java, the guy says two statements in bold and centered text,
something like “in java, variables only hold a referance to the object, not the actual object”
and “when an object is assigned to a variable, only the referance is copied, not the object”

i think objects in java are actually integers that act as pointers to the object, like ALOAD and ASTORE and stuff in bytecode work with that
edit: hmm… actually it depends on the JVM you’re using i think
edit2: oh hold on, theres the method System.identifyHashCode(Object) which seems to return the pointer, but you cant dereferance it, its only a int. so i guess JVMs have to use them as integers

Read full topic

item.title: Some Guidance
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

It is handy and even necessary some of the time, just don’t overuse it or it gets messy and unmanageable. Imagine a reference passed down through 10 method calls and/or being modified by multiple classes in perhaps more than one thread. Not good.

Read full topic

item.title: Some Guidance
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

Ah, thanks for telling me that. I had no idea. I don’t think I read in either of my books that that is how it worked.

And, yeah, Rictoo, you don’t even create the object

Edit: I can actually change some of my updater architecture because of this, hah.

Read full topic

item.title: Some Guidance
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Actually Pwnd is wrong, in yakman’s function, whatever was passed in as foundPoint will be changed outside of that function. In Java, only primitive types are copied when they are sent into functions, anything extending Object, however, is simply passed as a reference. If you don’t understand, write up an example, if you don’t know what I’m talking about I guess I can write up an example if need be.

edit: And Rictoo’s code throws a NullPointerException, think about it

Read full topic

item.title: Some Guidance
item.dc:creator: @Rictoo Rictoo
item.description:
@Rictoo wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:10, topic:152055”][quote author=yakman link=topic=207996.msg1825712#msg1825712 date=1192569029]
img is an object of type BufferedImage

public boolean findColor(Color color, Point foundPoint, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2) {
    for(int x = x1; x <= x2; x++)
        for(int y = y1; y <= y2; y++)
            if(img.getRGB(x, y) == color.getRGB()) {
                foundPoint.x = x;
                foundPoint.y = y;
                return true;
            }
    return false;
}

[/quote]

I didn’t think Java worked like that; foundPoint.x,y wouldn’t change outside of that method :/[/quote]

You’re right, this is what the code should be:

public Point findColor(Color color, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2) {
    Point foundPoint;
    for(int x = x1; x <= x2; x++)
        for(int y = y1; y <= y2; y++)
            if(img.getRGB(x, y) == color.getRGB()) {
                foundPoint.x = x;
                foundPoint.y = y;
                return foundPoint;
            }
    return null;
}

...

Point location;
if((location = findColor(new Color(bla), x1, y1, x2, y2)) != null) { ... }

Read full topic

item.title: Some Guidance
item.dc:creator: @Pwnd Pwnd
item.description:
@Pwnd wrote:

[quote=“yakman, post:6, topic:152055”]img is an object of type BufferedImage

public boolean findColor(Color color, Point foundPoint, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2) { for(int x = x1; x <= x2; x++) for(int y = y1; y <= y2; y++) if(img.getRGB(x, y) == color.getRGB()) { foundPoint.x = x; foundPoint.y = y; return true; } return false; } [/quote]

I didn’t think Java worked like that; foundPoint.x,y wouldn’t change outside of that method

Read full topic

item.title: Some Guidance
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Protosstribe, post:1, topic:152071”]Not sure, but isn’t it possible to use Robot even on Applets? If so, then that is another alternative.

Robots main purpose is just to simulate things (just like what you needed).[/quote]

Actually Robot does not simulate things, it actually moves your mouse, so if you are using robot the applet can not be minimized and you can not use your mouse.

Read full topic

item.title: Some Guidance
item.dc:creator: @yakman yakman
item.description:
@yakman wrote:

speedster239:

-Locating a findcolor function specifically to a loaded applet and with the ability of minimization

for this i think you would use your own copy of whats on the screen, most people would use http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4.2/docs/api/java/awt/image/BufferedImage.html
some people above my post have said a way to get this from an applet (or anything that extends Component)

BufferedImage has methods like getRGB(int x, int y) which returns the colour at that coordinate, for findcolor i guess it would look something like this

img is an object of type BufferedImage

public boolean findColor(Color color, Point foundPoint, int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2) {
    for(int x = x1; x <= x2; x++)
        for(int y = y1; y <= y2; y++)
            if(img.getRGB(x, y) == color.getRGB()) {
                foundPoint.x = x;
                foundPoint.y = y;
                return true;
            }
    return false;
}

Read full topic

item.title: Some Guidance
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Check out the com.cherokee.event package in cherokee:

http://cherokeeengine.svn.sourceforge.net/viewvc/cherokeeengine/src/com/cherokee/event/

That is how you would send mouse events to an applet, you can even use cherokee to do this for you. As to finding a color on a minimized screen, you would probably need to write a proxy to the Canvas class so that runescape draws to your class and you can do whatever you want with the data.

Read full topic
